content.user_title: Decompile Android APKs for security analysis
content.value_statement: Android apps hide their code in DEX bytecode. This skill provides complete guidance for using jadx to convert APK files into readable Java source code. Analyze app logic, find vulnerabilities, and extract hardcoded credentials with expert techniques.
actual_capabilities: Convert APK DEX bytecode to readable Java source code
Apply deobfuscation to restore meaningful class and method names
Search decompiled code for hardcoded credentials and API keys
Identify security vulnerabilities like SQL injection and weak crypto
Extract API endpoints and authentication mechanisms from apps
Export decompiled code as Gradle projects for further analysis
limitations: Requires jadx to be installed on your system
Cannot analyze heavily obfuscated or protected apps
Decompiled code is approximate, not exact original source

use_cases.title: Find vulnerabilities in apps
use_cases.description: Search for insecure crypto, SQL injection points, and hardcoded secrets in Android applications.

use_cases.title: Analyze companion app APIs
use_cases.description: Extract API endpoints and authentication logic from IoT device companion applications.

use_cases.title: Understand competitor apps
use_cases.description: Study how other apps implement features and handle security in your codebase.

prompt_templates.title: Basic decompile
prompt_templates.prompt: Decompile [app-name].apk using jadx with deobfuscation to [output-directory]

prompt_templates.title: Search secrets
prompt_templates.prompt: Search the decompiled code for API keys, passwords, and hardcoded credentials. Report all findings.

prompt_templates.title: Vulnerability scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze the decompiled code for common vulnerabilities including: weak encryption (MD5, DES), SQL injection risks, insecure storage (MODE_WORLD_READABLE), and WebView issues.

prompt_templates.title: API discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Extract all API endpoints, base URLs, and authentication mechanisms from the decompiled Android app. List each endpoint with its HTTP method.

best_practices: Always enable deobfuscation (--deobf) when analyzing production apps
Use multi-threading (-j) to speed up decompilation of large APKs
Combine static analysis (jadx) with dynamic analysis for complete results
anti_patterns: Skipping deobfuscation on obfuscated apps produces unreadable code
Analyzing without checking for anti-decompilation protection mechanisms
Trusting decompiled code as exact original source without verification

faq.question: What operating systems support jadx?
faq.answer: Jadx works on Windows, macOS, and Linux. Requires Java 8 or higher installed on your system.

faq.question: Can jadx decompile all Android apps?
faq.answer: Most apps decompile successfully. Apps with heavy obfuscation or commercial protection may have limited results.

faq.question: How does jadx compare to apktool?
faq.answer: Jadx produces readable Java code while apktool produces smali. Use jadx for code analysis, apktool for resource extraction.

faq.question: Is decompiled code safe to use?
faq.answer: Decompiled code is for analysis only. Never use decompiled code in your own projects due to licensing and copyright.

faq.question: Why does decompiled code look different from original?
faq.answer: Decompilation is an approximation. Compilers optimize code and remove comments, so output differs from original source.

faq.question: Can jadx extract strings and resources?
faq.answer: Yes, jadx can export resources separately or as a complete Gradle project with all assets and strings included.
